description:
Gymnoscopelus microlampas is a species of lanternfish found in the southern Atlantic and Indian Oceans. It is a small, slender fish that typically grows to a length of around 5-8 centimeters.

Gymnoscopelus microlampas belongs to the family Myctophidae, commonly known as the lanternfishes. Lanternfishes are a diverse group of small, mesopelagic fishes that are known for their distinctive bioluminescent photophores, which are light-producing organs that help them communicate, attract prey, and avoid predators in the deep ocean environment.

The species is distinguished by its small size, slender body shape, and the presence of a single row of photophores along the ventral surface of the body. Its coloration is typically silvery, with a darker dorsal region and lighter ventral areas.

Gymnoscopelus microlampas is found in the mesopelagic zone, typically between depths of 200 to 1,000 meters, where it feeds on small crustaceans and other zooplankton. It plays an important role in the oceanic food web, serving as a prey item for larger predatory fishes, seabirds, and marine mammals.
